title: Mahabharata | Part 50 | Duryodhana seeks Krishna's & Balarama's support | HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: Jaya Sri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda Sri Advaita Gadadhara Sri Vasadi Gauravatta Vrinda
segments.summary: The lecture begins with the chanting of prayers, including the Hare Krishna mantra and verses glorifying the spiritual master and Lord Chaitanya.

segments.key_quote: Duryodhana being the envious, greedy person that he was, he had no intention of returning the kingdom.
segments.summary: The speaker summarizes the previous episode, highlighting Duryodhana's refusal to return Indraprastha, Shakuni's calculations, and Dhritarashtra's attempt to broker peace through Sanjaya.

segments.key_quote: Duryodhana had already started intimating his allies, gathering different armies, and he was building up his army very well aware that his refusal to return Indraprastha to the Pandavas, which was rightfully theirs, would inevitably result in war.
segments.summary: The segment describes Krishna and Balarama's return to Dwaraka, Duryodhana's awareness of the impending war, and his plan to seek the support of the invincible Yadava army.

segments.key_quote: Although Ugrasena was the king of the Yadavas, still Krishna's word was always considered final.
segments.summary: Duryodhana arrives in Dwaraka seeking Krishna's support, knowing Krishna's influence over the Yadavas, and coincidentally meets Arjuna who has come for the same reason.

segments.key_quote: You came here first. But when I opened my eyes, the first person I saw was Arjuna.
segments.summary: Krishna, upon waking, greets both Duryodhana and Arjuna and offers them a choice: himself unarmed or his entire Narayani Sena, giving Arjuna the first opportunity to choose.

segments.key_quote: Krishna, doesn't matter that you don't lift arms, you don't do any activity, you just be by my side. That's enough for me.
segments.summary: Arjuna chooses Krishna over the army, expressing his deep devotion and prioritizing Krishna's presence above all else.

segments.key_quote: Although Krishna is the supreme person, he is the master of everyone, still Krishna loves to become subordinate to the commands of his devotee.
segments.summary: Krishna, overwhelmed by Arjuna's love, agrees to become his charioteer, illustrating the loving relationship between the Lord and his devotees.

segments.key_quote: Anandamayo Abhyasat by nature, the supreme lord being a person, he desires to enjoy.
segments.summary: Duryodhana, not giving up, approaches Balarama for support, while the speaker explains the concept of Krishna's expansions for the purpose of enjoyment and relationship.

segments.key_quote: I cannot even dream of opposing Krishna in any manner.
segments.summary: Balarama refuses to support Duryodhana, stating he cannot oppose Krishna and decides to go on pilgrimage, leaving Duryodhana disappointed.
Sanjaya arrives with Dhritarashtra's message of peace, but Yudhishthira insists on the return of Indraprastha as a condition for peace.

segments.key_quote: Duty of a Kshatriya is to fight or not in the face of injustice.
segments.summary: Sanjaya questions Yudhishthira's inclination towards war, prompting Yudhishthira to defend his position as a Kshatriya upholding Dharma, and seeking Krishna's judgment.

segments.key_quote: Now what right do you have to speak of Dharma?
segments.summary: Krishna expresses his anger, reminding Sanjaya of the injustices suffered by the Pandavas, particularly the disrobing of Draupadi, and condemning the Kauravas' actions.

segments.key_quote: Our message is very simple. Please hand over Indraprastha, which is rightfully ours, back to us.
segments.summary: The Pandavas reiterate their message, demanding the return of Indraprastha or at least five villages, with Bhima surprisingly advocating for peace.

segments.key_quote: I am waiting to fulfill my vow. I have vowed to kill Dushyasana and rip his heart out and drink his blood.
segments.summary: Bhima clarifies his desire for peace stems from compassion, but reaffirms his vow for revenge, prompting Krishna's laughter, and the lecture concludes with a promise of the next episode.
